docs.snippet: Cigars for Nonsmoking Fathers    For Father's Day, even a nonsmoker might enjoy a handsome chocolate cigar. Four six-inch cigars of dark chocolate perfumed with Armagnac and dusted with cocoa are packed in a wooden box, $26, at La Maison du Chocol...
docs.lead_paragraph: Cigars for Nonsmoking Fathers For Father's Day, even a nonsmoker might enjoy a handsome chocolate cigar. Four six-inch cigars of dark chocolate perfumed with Armagnac and dusted with cocoa are packed in a wooden box, $26, at La Maison du Chocolat, 25 East 73d Street. Then there are Fran's Fixations, small dark chocolate cigars wrapped in gold foil with flavored fillings, 95 cents each at Dean & DeLuca, 560 Broadway (at Prince Street), and 98 cents each at Butterfield Market, 1114 Lexington Avenue (at 77th Street). By mail they are $12 a dozen plus shipping from Fran's Chocolates in Seattle. To order: (800) 422-3726.

docs.abstract: Food Notes column reports on opening of new restaurant at Bloomingdale's called Lex and the all-vegetable menus being offered by some restaurants this summer (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Cook-Offs With Chilis and Apples Those who like to cook with chili peppers can enter a Jamaica, Queens, competition on Aug. 16 featuring New York City firefighters evaluating the heat. The contest, part of a summer festival at the Jamaica Market, 159-15 Jamaica Avenue, will award the best cooks with cash prizes of $25, $50 and $100. Those who want to enter must register in advance by calling Jacqueline Greene, (718) 291-0282, by 5 P.M. Friday.

docs.snippet: A Chelsea Harvest     Harvest, a new name and new identity for Peoples Gourmet, 198 Eighth Avenue (at 19th Street), has turned an industrial-looking, understocked fancy-food shop into a charming place decorated with old farm tools. Some department...
docs.abstract: Food Notes column notes some new food retailing in Manhattan; special Hungarian foods at UN delegates' dining room (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A Chelsea Harvest Harvest, a new name and new identity for Peoples Gourmet, 198 Eighth Avenue (at 19th Street), has turned an industrial-looking, understocked fancy-food shop into a charming place decorated with old farm tools. Some departments, notably cheese and pastry, still lack variety. Prepared foods are the highlight, including excellent shiitake mushroom and barley soup ($3.50 a pint), roast turkey breast marbled with herbs ($8.95 a pound), a salad of penne with mushrooms and garlic sausage ($6.95 a pound), roasted organic beets ($5.95 a pound) and heads of roasted organic garlic (60 cents each).

docs.snippet: Just Like Mexico     Su Casa Mexicana, a bakery and food shop at 695 Ninth Avenue (48th Street), would not be out of place in Oaxaca, Mexico. Customers can take a tray and tongs and help themselves to an array of eggy, flaky, custard-filled and al...
docs.lead_paragraph: Just Like Mexico Su Casa Mexicana, a bakery and food shop at 695 Ninth Avenue (48th Street), would not be out of place in Oaxaca, Mexico. Customers can take a tray and tongs and help themselves to an array of eggy, flaky, custard-filled and almond-scented pastries (75 cents to $1.50 each). Big sugared doughnuts, chilies, packaged foods and homemade tamales are also sold. This is a branch of the excellent Panaderia Don Paco Lopez, 4703 Fourth Avenue, Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Off the Menu The Patchwork of New York New York's new restaurants, recently open or about to be, mirror its tastes. Mesa City, 1059 Third Avenue (62d Street), a sibling of Mesa Grill, is Southwestern. Syrah, 1400 Second Avenue (73d Street), is American, with Ahmed El Shiekh, a French Culinary Institute graduate, pairing food with red wines made from the syrah grape. Cha Yen, 1165 Madison Avenue (86th Street), Eric Demarchelier's latest, is Thai. Scratch, 150 Spring Street (near Wooster Street), is global. And for French, there are Le Bistrot de Maxim's and Maxim's, reopened at 680 Madison Avenue (61st Street).

docs.snippet: More Keyboard Dancing   In recent years, the money to produce Broadway musicals has come from an increasingly diverse array of sources, from rock promoters to owners of theme parks. Now, to that unlikely list, add another: a toy store.   Executive...
docs.lead_paragraph: More Keyboard Dancing In recent years, the money to produce Broadway musicals has come from an increasingly diverse array of sources, from rock promoters to owners of theme parks. Now, to that unlikely list, add another: a toy store. Executives of F. A. O. Schwarz, the renowned Fifth Avenue toy emporium, say the company has completed negotiations to sign on as a major investor in and co-producer of "Big," a $9 million musical with music by David Shire and lyrics by Richard Maltby Jr. that is scheduled to open at the Shubert Theater in late April.

docs.snippet: NEW YORKERS love a love-hate relationship, and with Eli Zabar, they have their man. At his E.A.T. on Madison Avenue, shoppers are cordially invited to spend $3 on one brownie, $7 on one hallah, $12 on one chicken salad sandwich. But if they stop c...
docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORKERS love a love-hate relationship, and with Eli Zabar, they have their man. At his E.A.T. on Madison Avenue, shoppers are cordially invited to spend $3 on one brownie, $7 on one hallah, $12 on one chicken salad sandwich. But if they stop complaining long enough to get the object of their disaffection into their mouths -- especially the bread, Eli's bread, which in the last few years has transformed the staff of life in this town -- the outrage inevitably gives way to a rush of warm, mushy adjectives. They'll hate him in the morning. At 50, Mr. Zabar's bad-boy image persists, only now, everyone else wants lessons. The baby brother of Stanley and Saul Zabar, (61 and 66 respectively) the owners with Murray Klein of Zabar's on Broadway, Eli was always the renegade. Manners? Nah. He repeatedly told the press how rotten his competitors were, threw Giorgio DeLuca of Dean & DeLuca out of E.A.T., accusing him of spying for information on importers. And when his brothers offered him a job on the night shift at Zabar's after he asked to be a partner, he flat out quit and never looked back. Saul Zabar says: "I think he made the right choice. Both sides of the family have been successful, West Side and East Side. There's no jealousy. I think he's more up-front than the rest of us. That's his nature."

headline.main: AT WORK WITH: Eli Zabar; A New Hero for 'Waste Not, Want Not'

docs.snippet: LIKE most Angelenos, Linda Burum was used to getting on the freeway and driving past every neighborhood except her own. But seven years ago, she gave up the fast track for smaller streets with meandering turns and traffic lights, streets that freq...
docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE most Angelenos, Linda Burum was used to getting on the freeway and driving past every neighborhood except her own. But seven years ago, she gave up the fast track for smaller streets with meandering turns and traffic lights, streets that frequently lack signs. Her detours resulted in "A Guide to Ethnic Food in Los Angeles," which will be published this week by HarperPerennial. Ms. Burum, who appears to be as obsessed with arcane foods as she is easily confused by unfamiliar streets, was determined to map her hometown's ethnic frontiers and render its exotic tastes accessible. But would Lewis and Clark have risked so much for a meal?

headline.main: Mapping Out Ethnic Foods, Freeway By Freeway

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: GUIDE TO ETHNIC FOOD IN LOS ANGELES, A (BOOK)

docs.snippet: JANE BRODY'S GOOD FOOD GOURMET  Recipes and Menus for Delicious and Healthful Entertaining. By Jane E. Brody. Illustrated by Ray Skibinski. 602 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25.     THINK of Jane E. Brody, and words like "practical," "tho...

byline.original: By Lisa Tracy; Lisa Tracy is the author of "The Gradual Vegetarian."

docs.lead_paragraph: JANE BRODY'S GOOD FOOD GOURMET Recipes and Menus for Delicious and Healthful Entertaining. By Jane E. Brody. Illustrated by Ray Skibinski. 602 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25. THINK of Jane E. Brody, and words like "practical," "thorough" and "demystify" come to mind. She is, after all, the writer whose "Good Food Book" enabled us finally to understand cholesterol and lipoproteins. And although at first glance "down-to-earth" might seem to have little to do with "gourmet," Ms. Brody has done her magic again. "Jane Brody's Good Food Gourmet" demystifies entertaining for the beleaguered host or hostess of the 1990's. It is a thorough guide dedicated to the premise that one can feed guests while respecting their health. Under the new etiquette it seems that almost no one drinks alcohol, and it has become acceptable -- nay, understandable -- for guests to decline to go off their diets just because they are being entertained. After the briefest chapters on basic equipment, skills and sources of supplies for festive cooking, Ms. Brody gets to the more than 500 recipes that will make the most fidgety host feel equal to the task.

docs.snippet: As the range of products produced by biotechnology grows, so do the stakes in the battle to convince consumers that there are greater benefits than risks in tampering with nature. For the next few months, at least, the Monsanto Company is destined...
docs.lead_paragraph: As the range of products produced by biotechnology grows, so do the stakes in the battle to convince consumers that there are greater benefits than risks in tampering with nature. For the next few months, at least, the Monsanto Company is destined to lead the battle. Monsanto, the diversified chemical company that makes Ortho lawn and garden products and Nutrasweet, finds itself at the biotech front line because it won the race against companies like Eli Lilly, Upjohn and American Cyanamid to alter bacteria genetically into mini-factories producing a cow hormone called bovine somatotropin, or BST, that stimulates milk production. Monsanto received Food and Drug Administration clearance for its Posilac brand of BST last month and can begin selling it to American farmers on Feb. 3.

headline.main: In Battling for Biotech, Monsanto Is the Leader
